Q7.
::: {.question} **Disposition Effect and Taxes ‚Äî Brazilian Threshold ** **Context (read this first):** In Brazil, stock sales are **tax-exempt** if your **total proceeds from stock sales in the month** are **‚â§ BRL 20,000**. If your monthly proceeds **exceed BRL 20,000**, then **all capital gains realized that month** are taxed at **15%**. (Losses do not trigger tax and can typically be used to offset gains, but here we focus only on **today‚Äôs cash** to make the comparison clean.) This exercise compares two end-of-month choices to raise cash: - **Sell the winner (a position with a gain)** vs. **Sell the loser (a position with a loss)** - We deliberately set **the same proceeds (S)** for both sales so that any difference in **after-tax cash** comes **only from taxes** (not from different sale sizes). - This connects to the **disposition effect**: investors often prefer selling winners (to ‚Äúlock in gains‚Äù) and holding losers (to avoid realizing losses), but that behaviour can be **tax-inefficient** when the threshold is binding. You will: 1) compute **after-tax cash** if you sell the winner, 2) compute **after-tax cash** if you sell the loser, 3) compute the **advantage** (loser ‚àí winner). If **S > 20,000**, selling the winner may incur tax **today**, while selling the loser does **not**.
Leg Proceeds (BRL) Basis (BRL) Gain/Loss (BRL) Tax (BRL)
Sell winner (gain) 19931 11615 8316 0
Sell loser (loss) 19931 21447 -1516 0
**Assumptions:** One sale in the month, no other offsets, ignore costs; FIFO implicit. **Rule:** If **monthly proceeds** from stock sales **> BRL 20,000**, **all gains** that month are taxed at **15%**; otherwise, **exempt**. ::: {.question-block}
‚úÖ Step-by-step (winner leg with a gain)
‚Ä¢ Check the threshold: Monthly proceeds = 19931. Condition: S ‚â§ 20,000 ‚áí gains are exempt (0% tax).
‚Ä¢ Compute tax on the gain (if taxable): Gain = S ‚àí basis = 19931 ‚àí 11615 = 8316. Tax = 15% √ó Gain = 0.15 √ó 8316 = 0 BRL. (If the line above shows 0, it means the sale is **exempt** in this scenario.)
‚Ä¢ After-tax cash today: Proceeds ‚àí Tax = 19931 ‚àí 0 = 19931 BRL.

Why this matters: If the threshold binds, selling a winner creates **immediate tax outflow**, reducing today‚Äôs cash.
::: ::: {.question-block}
‚úÖ Step-by-step (loser leg with a loss)
‚Ä¢ Tax on losses: Realizing a loss does not trigger capital gains tax now; the tax due on this sale is 0 BRL. ‚Ä¢ After-tax cash today: Proceeds ‚àí Tax = 19931 ‚àí 0 = 19931 BRL.

Why this matters: Selling the loser yields the **same gross cash** as selling the winner in this setup, but with **no tax haircut** today. (Separately from this exercise, a realized loss may be used to offset gains in the month/year depending on the rules in force.)
::: ::: {.question-block}
‚úÖ Interpret and connect to investor behavior
Because **proceeds are equal** (S for both legs), the difference in after-tax cash is **purely the tax** on the winner (if any):
‚Ä¢ Advantage = After-tax(loser) ‚àí After-tax(winner) = 19931 ‚àí 19931 = 0 BRL.
‚Ä¢ If S ‚â§ 20,000, then Advantage = 0.

Key intuition (disposition effect): Many investors feel tempted to **sell winners** and **hold losers**. Under the Brazilian threshold rule, when **S > 20,000**, selling the winner can be **tax-inefficient today** (you pay 15% on the gain), whereas selling the loser gives you the **same cash** without a tax haircut. This illustrates how **tax rules** and **behavioral biases** interact: sticking to ‚Äúsell what went up‚Äù may **reduce** your **net cash today**, even if it feels psychologically rewarding.
::: :::
